info.game_comments:
David Madden game 20.  Victoria Groce ends David's streak.

Kelly Miyahara of the Clue Crew introduces herself during the closing credits.

jeopardy_round: A ROSE IS A ROSE IS A ROSE

(1, 1).clue: As of July 17, 2005 this Dan Brown novel had spent 120 weeks on the N.Y. Times' list

(2, 1).clue: His original lyrics to "This Land Is Your Land" mention the relief office & people who stood hungry

(3, 1).clue: This World War II radio propagandist was born on the Fourth of July, 1916

(4, 1).clue: In 1966 this French president pulled France out of NATO's integrated military structure

(6, 1).clue: It's a folded & grilled flour tortilla filled with cheese & often chicken; es muy buena!

(1, 2).clue: Appropriately, "A Salty Piece of Land" was penned by this "Margaritaville" singer

(2, 2).clue: In 1963 this trio breezed to No. 2 with "Blowin' In The Wind"

(3, 2).clue: Alliterative woman described in song here by Nat King Cole"Wild and wind-blown /That's how you've grown"

(4, 2).clue: This French emperor's own "Waterloo" came against the Germans in 1870

(6, 2).clue: 10-letter term for feeling stiff from horseback riding

(1, 3).clue: The CIA arranges a presidential pardon for mover & shaker Joel Backman in this John Grisham tale

(2, 3).clue: In 1997 he won a Grammy for his first new album in over a decade, simply titled "Pete"

(3, 3).clue: In 1956 Aussie Murray Rose became the 1st male swimmer to win 2 solo Olympic golds since this man in 1924

(4, 3).clue: In French, this French monk of the Middle Ages is known as Pierre l'Ermite

(5, 3).clue: The Dandie Dinmont,the Dandie Dinkum,the Dandie Doodahday

(6, 3).clue: We see this Southern California ctiy, originally named Indiana Colony, through rose-colored glasses

(1, 4).clue: The doctor was in, or rather on, the list with his environmentally themed "State of Fear"

(2, 4).clue: In 1958 this group heard here reigned at No. 1"...well /Hang down your head, Tom Dooley /Hang down your head..."

(3, 4).clue: In this Umberto Eco novel, William of Baskerville solves a murder like a medieval Sherlock Holmes

(4, 4).clue: "The Moon and Sixpence" was Somerset Maugham's roman a clef based on the life of this French artist

(6, 4).clue: Any war carried out under papal sanction

(1, 5).clue: This Tom Wolfe novel got the Presidential seal of approval when W. recommended it to friends

(2, 5).clue: After she sang the anthem "We Shall Overcome" at a 1963 march, her version of it hit the charts

(3, 5).clue: The 2 British royal houses of the Wars of the Roses

(4, 5).clue: This 19th century French politician & writer gave his name to a style of steak

(6, 5).clue: His rule of Syria included the 1982 killing of perhaps 20,000 in the city of Hamah

(1, 1).clue: In the 1700s Rosalba Carriera, whose work is seen here, was the first to popularize these pigment sticks

(3, 1).clue: Lactobacillus bulgaricus & Streptococcus thermophilus are the usual bacteria that culture this food

(4, 1).clue: The title of the article Donald Trump penned on her was "The Domestic Diva Is Back"

(5, 1).clue: "Sonnets from the Portuguese" was so named because "Portuguese" was this man's nickname for its author

(6, 1).clue: In 1484 he tried to get King John II of Portugal to finance his transoceanic trip

(1, 2).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew makes some cartoon trees grow.)  By enlarging the nearest part of the image, this technique adds the illusion of depth

(2, 2).clue: 3 strangers are united by tragedy in "___ Grams"

(3, 2).clue: They're the two complementary cosmic forces represented here

(4, 2).clue: The World Health Org. says his & his wife's foundation has "already saved the lives of 670,000 children"

(5, 2).clue: "When I consider how my light is spent" begins this sonnet about his loss of sight

(6, 2).clue: In 1763 Portugal's South American colonies were unified with the capital set in this city

(1, 3).clue: Encaustic painting, used since ancient times, applies this animal product to a rigid surface & fixes it with heat

(3, 3).clue: The Rockefeller Foundation scientists who developed a vaccine for this "colorful" disease often caught it

(4, 3).clue: The article on economist Jeffrey Sachs was by this Dubliner who worked with Sachs on world debt relief

(5, 3).clue: This Romantic began his "England in 1819", "An old, mad, blind, despised and dying king"

(6, 3).clue: The name of Cape Agulhas, the southernmost point of this continent, is Portuguese for "needles"

(1, 4).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew shows off a blank canvas.)  This step in prepping a canvas doesn't mean measuring; it means adding a layer of glue so the paint doesn't sink in & lose its color

(2, 4).clue: Inspired by the director's own early life:"The ___ Blows"

(3, 4).clue: In Judaism the holiest of all days is this day of atonement

(4, 4).clue: The headline of this man's article was "Dear Leader Goes Nuclear"

(5, 4).clue: The "Canzoniere" by this Tuscan contained over 300 sonnets to an idealized beloved he had never met

(6, 4).clue: Before 1974 this country with a hyphenated name was known as Portuguese Guinea

(1, 5).clue: (Kelly of the Clue Crew fiddles with some classical whiskers.)  This term for deliberately blurring an area, as Titian did here, sounds like a combination of "scramble" & "jumble"

(2, 5).clue: Set on New Year's Eve:"___ Cigarettes"

(3, 5).clue: For many years, Aden, this country's second-largest city, was a British Crown Colony

(4, 5).clue: After he defeated Alan Keyes for an Illinois senate seat, Time asked if he was "The future of the Democratic Party?"

(5, 5).clue: Perhaps the most distinguished 20th century sonneteer was this German poet in works like "Sonnets to Orpheus"

(6, 5).clue: 1494's Treaty of Tordesillas aimed to settle a dispute between Portugal & this nation over New World territories

(0, 0).clue: In 1950 Pius XII was Pontifex Maximus; exactly 2,000 years earlier, this man held a title of the same name
